A field is a commutative division ring.
A proper ideal $\mathfrak{p} \subsetneq R$ in a ring $R$ is called a prime ideal if for elements $a, b \in R$, $ab \in \mathfrak{p}$ implies $a \in \mathfrak{p}$ or $b \in \mathfrak{p}$.
Does the concept of a/an Field need to be defined for a definition of a/an Prime Ideal to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: The concept of a prime ideal is defined within the context of ring theory. A prime ideal is a specific type of subset within a ring, which itself is a more general algebraic structure than a field. The definition of a prime ideal does not require the ring to be a field; it only requires the ring to have the basic properties of a ring (a set equipped with two binary operations satisfying certain axioms).\n\nA field, by definition, is a commutative division ring, which means every non-zero element has a multiplicative inverse. While fields are special types of rings, the definition of a prime ideal does not necessitate the ring to have the properties of a field. The prime ideal concept applies to any ring, not just fields. Therefore, the existence or definition of a field is not necessary for the definition of a prime ideal to make sense.
